copies.subject: Should I close your file?
copies.body:
Hi {{first_name}},

I've reached out a few times and haven't heard back.

I totally get it - you're busy and this might not be the right time.

I'm going to assume improving ad performance isn't a priority for {{company}} right now and close out your file.

If anything changes down the road, feel free to reach out. I'll be here.

All the best,
{{sender_name}}

copies.subject: Breaking up is hard to do
copies.body:
{{first_name}},

This is my last email, I promise.

I've been trying to connect about helping {{company}} with your paid advertising, but I'm getting the sense the timing isn't right.

No hard feelings - I'll stop filling up your inbox.

If you ever want to chat about cutting your ad costs, just reply to this email. I'll still be here.

{{sender_name}}

P.S. - If you've been ignoring me because my emails are terrible, I'd genuinely appreciate the feedback.
copies.notes: Light humor, self-deprecating PS often gets responses

standard_3_email.description: Most common sequence - curiosity opener, value followup, soft breakup

aggressive_5_email.description: More persistent sequence for high-value prospects

soft_2_email.description: Minimal sequence for warm leads or referrals

best_practices: First email should be 100-150 words max
Each follow-up should add new value, not just 'checking in'
Breakup emails often get highest reply rates - make them count
Test different styles to find what works for your audience
Reply-style subjects ('Re: ...') increase open rates but use sparingly
One CTA per email - don't confuse the reader
